column4: if i want to set upa basic file server/bittorrenting box that would only be accessed via ssh from my main computer, what would be the best ubuntu setup for that? maybe ubuntu server+xfce or fluxbox?
common wisdom is not to use any graphical interface on a secure server at all
oh ok, i've never done the whole ssh thing before how exactly would it work?
so jut ubuntu server then and ssh to it?
read up on it on the web, it's really not trivial
!ssh
and then my current ocmputer will handle the windowing managing?
not sure what you mean, if your server has graphical interface installed, yes you can remotely use them from the local box
but you're better off not using any gr. interface on a public server
.. because of security
so if i use ssh to remotely login to it, then would i have to do everything by the command line?
yes you can remotely administer the server from command line (or using other interfaces). Linux is ideal for such things -- but like i said it's not trivial and you need to learn stuff
it will be on the same intranet as my main box and behidn a firewall and really only for my use and not visible to the outside, ....so would having a graphical interface be bad

in that case, if the firewall is tight enough, gr interface will be ok. but if your server, even being behind the firewall, is for public use, things are different. it depends a lot on concrete conditions
it wont be for pulbic use, well not this year, next year when im at college it will be...but that will be a next summer proejct
right now its just for my use

ok in that case just install normal ubuntu (with desktop) or xubuntu on the server, plus the bittorrent server software. i can't tell you anything about the latter, though. In any case make sure the firewall is tight enough.
isn't there a special server ubuntu version?
yes but as it is common with Linux to do without graph. interface for servers, it is not included (i think) in ubuntu's server setup

to be frank, ubuntu server is just some kind of stripped down ubuntu if you ask me ... because there are better Linux distros for servers ... anyway it will help you to have the same distro on both server and desktop
thanks
there's a ton of documentation on the net about Linux servers, just grab it and read, read, read
